newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish former minister testifies in scandal.
newsitem.headline: Turkish former minister testifies in scandal.

text.p: A former interior minister who quit in a scandal over links between Turkish officials and organised crime testified to a parliamentary inquiry on Thursday, Anatolian news agency said.
It quoted members of the inquiry, which is closed to the media, as saying ex-minister Mehmet Agar refused to answer questions on aspects of the scandal because they were before the courts.
Legal authorities are studying the possibility of lifting Agar's parliamentary immunity to try him on charges of abusing his position.
He has been accused by the media of involvement in the disappearance of a secret service officer and supplying police documents to a fugitive, rightwing gangster.
Agar is an MP from Deputy Prime Minister Tansu Ciller's True Path Party, a junior partner in the coalition government.
He defended the reputation of the security forces: "I am with them with all my heart. I am at peace and relaxed enough to give an account of everything," Anatolian quoted him as saying.
Agar resigned last November after the scandal came to light when a senior policeman, a murder suspect and an MP were discovered together in a car involved in a fatal crash.
